description: From Middle English bunsen (“to beat, thump”), perhaps imitative. Compare Low German bunsen (“to beat”), Dutch bonzen (“to thump, knock, throb”), and akin to bonken (“to bang, smash”), and possibly English bang.

entries.meaning: A change of direction of motion after hitting the ground or an obstacle.
examples: Synonym: rebound

entries.meaning: A movement up and then down (or vice versa), once or repeatedly.
examples: Synonyms: bob, (repeated) bobbing, (repeated) bouncing

entries.meaning: (Internet) An email that returns to the sender because of a delivery failure.
The sack, dismissal.
A bang, boom.
examples: I don't value her resentment the bounce of a cracker.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A drink based on brandy.W
(archaic) A heavy, sudden, and often noisy, blow or thump.
examples: The bounce burst ope the door.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Bluster; brag; untruthful boasting; audacious exaggeration; an impudent lie; a bouncer.
examples: And, in fact, the whole story is a bounce of his own. For, in a most abusive letter which he wrote “to a learned person,” (meaning Wallis the mathematician,) he gives quite another account of the matter

entries.meaning: Scyliorhinus canicula, a European dogfish.
examples: Synonyms: houndfish, morgay, small-spotted catshark

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A genre of hip-hop music of New Orleans, characterized by often lewd call-and-response chants.
(slang, African-American Vernacular, uncountable) Drugs.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:recreational drug

entries.meaning: (slang, African-American Vernacular, uncountable) Swagger.
(slang, African-American Vernacular, uncountable) A good beat in music.
(slang, African-American Vernacular, uncountable) A talent for leaping.
examples: Synonyms: ups, mad ups
Them pro-ballers got bounce!

verbs.description: bounce (third-person singular simple present bounces, present participle bouncing, simple past and past participle bounced)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To change the direction of motion after hitting an obstacle.
examples: Synonyms: bounce back, rebound
The tennis ball bounced off the wall before coming to rest in the ditch.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move quickly up and then down (or vice versa), once or repeatedly.
examples: Synonym: bob
He bounces nervously on his chair.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to move quickly up and down, or back and forth, once or repeatedly.
examples: He bounced the child on his knee.
The children were bouncing a ball against a wall.

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) To suggest or introduce (an idea, etc.) to (off or by) someone, in order to gain feedback.
examples: I'm meeting Bob later to bounce some ideas off him about the new product range.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To leap or spring suddenly or unceremoniously; to bound.
examples: She bounced happily into the room.

entries.meaning: To move rapidly (between).
(intransitive, informal, of a cheque/check) To be refused by a bank because it is drawn on insufficient funds.
examples: We can’t accept further checks from you, as your last one bounced.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To fail to cover (have sufficient funds for) (a draft presented against one's account).
examples: He tends to bounce a check or two toward the end of each month, before his payday.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang) To leave.
examples: Let’s wrap this up, I gotta bounce.

entries.meaning: (US, slang, dated) To eject violently, as from a room; to discharge unceremoniously, as from employment.
examples: Nobody took umbrage and bounced me out of the Union for being a pro.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang, African-American Vernacular, sometimes followed by with) To have sexual intercourse.
examples: Synonyms: bang, do it, have sex; see also Thesaurus:copulate

entries.meaning: (transitive, air combat) To attack unexpectedly.
examples: The squadron was bounced north of the town.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, electronics) To turn power off and back on; to reset.
examples: See if it helps to bounce the router.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, Internet, of an e-mail message) To return undelivered.
examples: What’s your new email address? The old one bounces.
The girl in the bar told me her address was thirsty@example.com, but my mail to that address was bounced back by the server.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, aviation) To land hard and lift off again due to excess momentum.
examples: The student pilot bounced several times during his landing.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, skydiving) To land hard at unsurvivable velocity with fatal results.
examples: After the mid-air collision, his rig failed and he bounced.

entries.meaning: (transitive, sound recording) To mix (two or more tracks of a multi-track audio tape recording) and record the result onto a single track, in order to free up tracks for further material to be added.
examples: Bounce tracks two and three to track four, then record the cowbell on track two.

entries.meaning: (slang, archaic) To bully; to scold.
(slang, archaic) To boast; to bluster.
(archaic) To strike or thump, so as to rebound, or to make a sudden noise; to knock loudly.
examples: Another bounces as hard as he can knock.
